messageBody:
Slava --

I don't believe I said that JUnit is a "developer-only" testing tool.
JUnit is a testing tool, simply.

This being a JUnit list (and not a "Software Testing" list), I'd rather
not get too immersed into a discussion about overall [organizational]
software testing best practices.

That said, I do feel unable to decline from commenting that, while as a
general rule I certainly love an abundance of JUNit use (it's the
coolest!), I fail to see how the average someone who categorizes
themselves as a "Quality Assurance (QA)" tester would be wisely spending
their time writing, reading, and/or maintaining [Java-based] JUnit tests
with the existence of other more suitable "non-techie" fronted automated
testing tools...or when they could be simply testing the system directly.

As for the perceived benefit of having "a common platform", I think that
might be true only as long as you intend to staff only people versed in
that platform's common language for as long as the product is in
development.

So, in short, I'm not challenging JUnit's suitability for "functional"
(integration?) tests, but rather it's suitability as a "one-size fits
all" testing tool for your organization.


Cheers...
--MB

p.s.// can you tell me what "HTH" stands for?

Slava Imeshev wrote:
>
>
> Mike,
>
> > I'm curious about how (why?) "QA" is using JUnit tests.
>
> Having a common platform that runs it all is good. Unit tests and
> using JUnit overgrew "developer-only" testing long ago. Sooner
> (better) or later they become functional tests, user acceptance tests
> and what not.
>
> So, to me limiting test run by QA is a natural requirements. We use
> Ant's <batchtest if="..."> to select what test groups should be run in
> a particular case.
